name: Zilker Metropolitan Park
description: Austin's iconic 350-acre central park with Barton Springs, botanical gardens, festivals, and endless recreation.
longDescription: Zilker Metropolitan Park is Austin's most beloved public space—350 acres of green space in the heart of the city that serves as the community's shared backyard. The park encompasses Barton Springs Pool, Zilker Botanical Garden, Austin Nature & Science Center, the Zilker Hillside Theater, and vast open fields. It borders Lady Bird Lake and connects to the hike-and-bike trail. Zilker hosts Austin City Limits Music Festival, the Trail of Lights, Zilker Kite Festival, and countless other events. The Zilker Zephyr miniature train is a family favorite. Proximity to Zilker Park is one of the most valued features in Austin real estate.
tips: Barton Springs has small entry fee

name: Barton Creek Greenbelt
description: 12-mile limestone canyon trail system with swimming holes, rock climbing, and Hill Country hiking in the heart of Austin.
longDescription: The Barton Creek Greenbelt is Austin's premier outdoor escape—a 12-mile stretch of trails winding through a limestone canyon with swimming holes, natural springs, rock climbing walls, and lush vegetation. The trail system offers something for everyone: easy walks on the main trail, challenging scrambles to remote swimming holes, and bouldering opportunities at numerous limestone outcrops. Popular spots include Sculpture Falls, Twin Falls, and the Gus Fruh pool. Water levels vary seasonally, with spring being the best time for swimming. The Greenbelt is one of Austin's most treasured natural resources and a major draw for outdoor enthusiasts considering a move to the city.
address: 3755 Capital of Texas Hwy, Austin, TX 78746
tips: Check water levels before going for swimming

name: McKinney Falls State Park
description: State park within Austin city limits featuring waterfalls, swimming, hiking trails, and camping.
longDescription: McKinney Falls State Park is a remarkable natural treasure within the Austin city limits, offering two beautiful waterfalls, swimming areas, hiking and biking trails, and camping facilities. Upper and Lower McKinney Falls cascade over limestone ledges into swimming pools, creating natural gathering spots. The park's trails wind through diverse habitats, and the ruins of the historic McKinney homestead add historical interest. The campground provides a genuine state park camping experience just minutes from downtown. It's a stunning reminder that Austin's natural beauty extends well beyond the Greenbelt.

name: Pease Park
description: Historic Austin park with ancient Kingsbury Oak, Shoal Creek trail access, and recent extensive renovation.
longDescription: Pease Park is one of Austin's oldest parks, dating to 1875, and has undergone a stunning multi-million dollar renovation that restored and enhanced this beloved green space. The park stretches along Shoal Creek, featuring the massive Kingsbury Oak tree (one of Austin's most photographed trees), modern playgrounds, splash pads, and event spaces. The renovated Treehouse pavilion is an architectural gem. The park connects to the Shoal Creek Trail, providing a green corridor through central Austin. Its central location between downtown, Clarksville, and Old West Austin makes it accessible to some of Austin's most desirable neighborhoods.

name: Red Bud Isle
description: Off-leash dog park and nature area on a peninsula in Lady Bird Lake, beloved by dog owners and nature lovers.
longDescription: Red Bud Isle is Austin's most beloved dog park—a 13-acre peninsula jutting into Lady Bird Lake where dogs run off-leash and splash in the water while their owners socialize on the trails and shores. The heavily wooded island feels surprisingly remote despite being minutes from downtown. Walking trails loop through the forest, and the shoreline provides ample water access for swimming dogs. It's also a popular spot for birdwatching and quiet nature walks. Red Bud Isle represents the best of Austin's relationship with nature—wild spaces preserved within the urban fabric.
tips: Dogs must be under voice control

name: Bull Creek District Park
description: Popular swimming and hiking spot with limestone creek beds, rope swings, and family-friendly wading areas.
longDescription: Bull Creek District Park is one of Austin's most popular natural swimming destinations, featuring a limestone creek bed with multiple swimming holes, rope swings, and gentle wading areas perfect for families. The upper falls area has deeper pools for swimming, while the lower creek sections offer shallow, child-friendly water. Hiking trails wind along the creek through beautiful Hill Country terrain. The park is especially popular on hot summer days when the spring-fed creek provides cooling relief. It's a cherished neighborhood resource for the surrounding residential areas.

name: Emma Long Metropolitan Park
description: Lake Austin waterfront park with swimming, camping, boat ramps, and Hill Country setting.
longDescription: Emma Long Metropolitan Park sits on the shores of Lake Austin, offering one of the few public swimming and camping spots on this otherwise private lake. The park features a sandy beach area, boat ramp, picnic facilities, and campsites set among mature trees on the limestone hillside. The Turkey Creek Trail provides Hill Country hiking with lake views. For those who love Lake Austin but don't live on it, Emma Long provides access to this beautiful stretch of the Colorado River.
tips: Beach area fills fast on weekends

name: Walnut Creek Metropolitan Park
description: North Austin park with extensive mountain bike trails, swimming pool, and sports facilities.
longDescription: Walnut Creek Metropolitan Park is a 293-acre park in North Austin that has become the city's premier mountain biking destination. The extensive trail system features technical single-track for experienced riders alongside beginner-friendly routes. Beyond biking, the park offers a swimming pool, basketball courts, baseball diamonds, and a disc golf course. The diverse ecosystems along Walnut Creek provide habitat for wildlife and pleasant walking trails. For North Austin residents, Walnut Creek is an essential community recreational resource.
tips: Trails can be muddy after rain

name: Ann and Roy Butler Hike-and-Bike Trail
description: Austin's iconic 10-mile lakeside trail connecting neighborhoods, parks, and downtown with running, walking, and cycling.
longDescription: The Ann and Roy Butler Hike-and-Bike Trail is Austin's most popular outdoor amenity—a 10-mile paved trail that encircles Lady Bird Lake, connecting downtown, South Congress, Zilker Park, East Austin, and numerous neighborhoods. The trail is alive with runners, walkers, cyclists, and strollers from dawn to well past dark (it's lit in most sections). The Boardwalk section over the lake is an engineering marvel and a favorite scenic stretch. Multiple kayak and paddleboard rental points along the trail make it easy to transition from land to water. For home buyers, proximity to the trail directly impacts property values.
address: Lady Bird Lake Trail, Austin, TX 78701
tips: Multiple water and kayak access points

name: Covert Park at Mount Bonnell
description: Austin's highest point at 775 feet with panoramic views of Lake Austin, the Hill Country, and the city skyline.
longDescription: Covert Park at Mount Bonnell provides access to Austin's highest point, offering some of the most spectacular views in Central Texas. The 102-step climb to the summit rewards visitors with panoramic vistas of Lake Austin, the rolling Hill Country, and the Austin skyline. The park is one of Austin's oldest tourist attractions and remains a favorite for sunset viewing, proposals, and photography. The small park at the summit has picnic tables and viewing areas along the cliff edge. Early morning visits offer the most peaceful experience.

name: Deep Eddy Pool
description: Texas's oldest swimming pool, spring-fed and open year-round, with lap swimming and a historic wading area.
longDescription: Deep Eddy Pool holds the distinction of being the oldest swimming pool in Texas, dating to the 1910s when a man named A.J. Eilers built a concrete dam in a natural spring-fed eddy of the Colorado River. Today, the spring-fed pool operates year-round with constant cool water temperatures. The pool is divided into a lap pool and a shallow wading area for families. The historic bathhouse and pecan tree-shaded grounds create an atmosphere that connects swimmers to over a century of Austin history. It's a neighborhood treasure for the surrounding Clarksville and West Austin areas.

name: Mary Moore Searight Metropolitan Park
description: South Austin park with miles of trails, disc golf, sports fields, and off-leash dog area.
longDescription: Mary Moore Searight Metropolitan Park is a 344-acre park in South Austin offering diverse recreational opportunities. The park features an extensive trail system popular with mountain bikers and hikers, an 18-hole disc golf course, sports fields, an off-leash dog area, and a community garden. The terrain includes wooded areas, open meadows, and Slaughter Creek crossings. It's a vital green space for the growing South Austin community and provides a natural counterbalance to the area's suburban development.
tips: Lots of room to spread out
